title: HRM - The Ultimate Employee Onboarding Guide with 4C's
headline: Learn how to quickly get newly hired employees up and running with this free online course on onboarding.
description: A whopping 16% of employees leave their organization within the first week of joining and more than 25% go within the first three months. In this course, you will learn how to lower these statistics in yoru organisation by understanding the art and science of employee onboarding using the ‘4Cs’ concept. We then use case studies to equip you with the knowledge and skills required to successfully establish and onboard new hires in any institution.

courseDescription:
Losing employees soon after they come on board represents a considerable cost to organizations. However, effective onboarding can curb this loss and is necessary for every organization looking to maximize employee engagement and retention. In this course, we will explore the first days of an employee’s journey in a company using two case studies and discover how to make them enjoyable. We will also reveal the common challenges faced by those in human resource management (HRM) and gain some insight into dealing with them.

Human resources managers are typically saddled with making new employees comfortable and getting them up to speed within the company. This course will provide a step-by-step guide to make this process as smooth as possible. We will introduce you to the ‘4Cs’ of employee onboarding - compliance, clarification, connection and culture - and see how they could be used as a framework to simplify the onboarding process. We will also provide the contents needed for an employee onboarding kit and a welcome mail.

The onboarding process is often plagued with everyday challenges like information overload for new employees and burnout for human resource (HR) managers. New employees can also be confused by a lack of clarity about their roles. We will explore these and other challenges when onboarding new employees and uncover some proven strategies for preventing their incidence. This course will prove incredibly useful to HR managers and would be easy to relate to since we present the content as part of case studies. So why wait? Start this course now to gain insights into the onboarding process and how to improve it.

Start Course Now

• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Summarize what employee onboarding is and the phases of Employee Onboarding.
    • Indicate the concepts and methodology of effective onboarding by understanding and implementing the 4 C's of Effective Employee Onboarding, with a case study example (solved).
    • Outline an employee onboarding program keeping in mind the important 4 C's of the onboarding concept.

    • State what a new hire in the organization expects on the first day of joining.
    • List the contents of an Onboarding Kit which complies with the 4 C's of onboarding.

  • What is Employee Onboarding?

  • Onboarding is a human resources term that refers to the process of introducing and integrating a newly hired employee into an organization. 

    Also known as organizational socialization, onboarding is an important part of helping employees understand their new position and job requirements - while also helping them learn about the organizational structure, culture, mission, vision and values.

    Onboarding is important because it acclimates employees to their roles, the company's philosophies, and what the company has to offer. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • It also engages employees, creating workers committed to the company's success and helps retain new hires by making them feel like team members. A successful onboarding strategy will reduce attrition and increase employee engagement, both of which impact your customers' satisfaction.

  • Onboarding Checklist and Welcome Mail

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • We need to have a pre-joining checklist as well as post-joining checklists in place, covering the most important things to be completed before new employees join as well as after joining. It includes some of the important points like;
     
    1. Asking the new hire to send their personal data to enter into the company HRIS. This could include ID proofs, contact details, passport, tax and bank, family details, certificate copies, etc. Ask the new hire to come with any necessary documents on the day of joining.
  • 2. Send a welcome mail before the arrival of a new joiner, which includes the arrival time of the first day, a copy of the office map, office dress code, and a first-day agenda. Send a joining announcement mail to the new hire’s reporting manager, his department and other stakeholders

    3. Before the arrival of a new hire, collect and send the new hire’s banking details to the accounts department to set up payroll; ID creation details to IT department, Office Admin who can set up a workstation. All these should be sorted out before the arrival of the employee to ensure they do not waste time waiting for configurations to happen.

  • What things do New Hires expect on the First Day?

  • Most new hires prefer to have basic facilities set up for them before they arrive, and they are least likely to accept any surprises, issues or downtime on their first day. Waiting a lot is a big NO. Hence, Prepare your new hire’s desk and tech, including their laptop, monitor, phone, mouse, keyboard, headset and so on.

  • Things to prepare before new hire arrives
    • Arrange for the new hire’s ID card, building access fob and personal locker.
    • Order the new employee's business cards and/or nameplates.
    • Ask for the new hire’s T-shirt size and place an order for a work uniform and/or a company T-shirt as a welcome gift.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Employee Onboarding is the process of introducing and integrating a newly hired employee into an organization.
    • The 4 phases of onboarding are Orientation, Role-specific training, Transition, and Ongoing Development.
    • The 4 C's of onboarding - Compliance, Clarification, Culture and Connection - are crucial aspects of a successful employee onboarding program.
    • Compliance involves covering key policies and taking acknowledgement from the new hire. This could relate to anti-harassment, personal conduct standards, progressive disciplinary action, security and so on. 
    • Clarification involves covering job-specific details such as team and project details, project training plan, performance expectations, administrative policies and so on.
    • Culture involves helping the hire understand company norms and involves activities such as arranging weekly lunches with executives, courses on company values, meeting the business unit head and so on.
    • Connection involves establishing relationships and networks by assigning a peer mentor/buddy, framing a 3-level buddy program, working with cross-functional teams, functional training and organising 1-on-1s with people new hires will closely work with.
    • The 3-level buddy program involves making someone a buddy for the new hire on 3 levels - role buddy, culture buddy & leader buddy.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Describe what a good employee onboarding process looks like.
    • Recognize the challenges faced by HR professionals/onboarding facilitators in organizations and discuss how to overcome them.
    • Outline the challenges commonly faced by the new joiners in the organizations and how to address them effectively. 
    • Analyze how to avoid exhaustion faced by HR team members or Onboarding Facilitators while multi-tasking during the new hire onboarding process.

  • A Good Onboarding Process Flow

  • The Onboarding Process Flow basically consists of the steps involved right from the new joiner coming into contact with your organization to the onboarding and training. An ideal onboarding process flow looks like this:
    1. Releasing the offer letter.
    2. Offer acceptance by employee.
    3. Waiting period.
    4. The day of joining.
    5. Coordination with other departments.
    6. Orientation, training & the first quarter plan.

  • What Makes Employees Happy? Feedback Management

  • Let us define the problems faced by Rahul in this case study, related to employee onboarding.
  • An employee has resigned abruptly - just after a month, despite giving their orientation exercise a 5-star review.

    What could be the reason behind attrition during the first few months of joining?

    Rahul does not know what is working and what isn't for new employees during onboarding and must find out.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Early Attrition is a common HRM problem, and Rahul needs to tackle this like any other competent HR manager with engagement and retention strategies. Early Attrition can be expensive for organizations as a lot of money is invested in recruiting a new hire. Failing to retain hires means the organization loses its recruitment investment. 

    Hence, HR Professionals need to devise clear, concise, and concrete onboarding plans that help new joiners stay with the company, thereby helping to control recruitment costs involved in replacing the new hires' vacant positions. New hires' feedback from day 1 is vital in helping organizations understand what makes an employee happy and what will not.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Orientation is short-term, while onboarding is long-term.
    • Some of the challenges faced during onboarding by new hires are Information overload on Day 1, lack of clarity on their role, and what kind of performance is expected by the organization.
    • Some of the challenges faced by HR teams during onboarding include too much time spent on onboarding activities, leaving very little time for other productive HRM tasks and an inability to meet new joiners' expectations constantly.
    • Focus on reducing paperwork and encourage engagement with culture and productivity. Avoid information overload on Day 1 by automating and reducing paperwork.
    • Align managers, team leaders and others with the onboarding process for new hires. Have a functional training plan in place, and facilitate continuous cultural connection and learning.
    • For feedback collection and management, questionnaires are not enough. You should also conduct Exit Analyses, 360-degree feedback and Interactive HR forums.
    • Learn to Say "No!" to people. Some tips for multitasking include focusing on only what’s relevant, having updated FAQs & guides, taking breaks and handing out key contact details to new joiners.
    • You should list out what can/cannot be done as per your schedule and keep managers and other stakeholders informed.
